name: ENERGY SYS, RES & TECH

values.comments:
The course presents a comprehensive overview of the global demand for energy, and the resource availability and technology used in its current and future supply. Through a personal energy audit, students are made aware of the extensive role that energy plays in modern life, both directly, through electricity and transportation fuel, and indirectly in the manufacturing of goods they use. The course covers how that energy is supplied, the anticipated global growth in energy demand, the resource availability and the role of science and technology in meeting that demand in a world concerned about climate change. The roles of conservation, improved efficiency and renewable energy in meeting future demand in a sustainable, environmentally benign way are covered.

Overall, students agreed that the course material was “interesting” and “enjoyable.” Many students reported learning a lot about energy systems from this class, describing it as an “overload of information but very in depth.”

Some students felt that Professor Jackson was “kind, friendly, and approachable,” but that, at times, he could be “uninspiring and dull.” Some students felt that the professor relied on his 35 years experience doing energy efficiency research at Exxon Mobil to give a comprehensive analysis on the topic. One student commented that the course was “helpful for showing the past, present, and future of world energy.”

Many students agreed that homework assignments were “well-designed” and “closely related to the real life,” resulting in the development of important analytical skills. Students reported that there were quizzes and homework assignments every week, making the word load very heavy. Students also generally felt that quizzes and tests were harshly graded, with little to no partial credit given.
